results_summary: OEA treatment restored prepulse inhibition (PPI) deficits in socially stressed mice and differentially affected anxiety and depressive-like behaviors in males and females, though it did not alter stress-induced neuroinflammatory markers (IL-6 and CX3CL1).
population_specificity: Adult male and female mice subjected to social defeat (SD) or vicarious social defeat (VSD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of oleoylethanolamide (OEA) in intestinal homeostasis and its interplay with gut microbiota, focusing on its effects on inflammation, metabolism, and microbial composition.
results_summary: OEA levels fluctuate with nutrient status, decreasing during fasting and increasing upon refeeding. OEA treatment in rodents showed protective effects against inflammation and altered gut microbiota composition, suggesting a regulatory role in gastrointestinal homeostasis.
population_specificity: Rodents (specific species not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory properties of OEA in the Purkinje Cell Degeneration (PCD) mouse model, focusing on its potential to mitigate neuroinflammation caused by neuronal loss.
results_summary: OEA modulated cerebellar neuroinflammation by initially increasing proinflammatory gene expression but decreasing it over time, enhanced anti-inflammatory and neuroprotective factors, reduced microglial density, shifted microglial phenotype toward anti-inflammatory states, and prevented leukocyte infiltration.
population_specificity: Purkinje Cell Degeneration (PCD) mice with aggressive cerebellar Purkinje neuron loss.
study_duration: Different time points after OEA administration (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) on cocaine reward-related behavior and relapse-related gene expression in the striatum and hippocampus.
results_summary: OEA administration did not affect cocaine-induced conditioned place preference (CPP) acquisition but prevented drug-induced reinstatement. OEA also blocked cocaine-induced increases in dopamine receptor D1 gene expression and reduced striatal dopamine receptor D2 and cannabinoid receptor 1 gene expression.
population_specificity: Male OF1 mice
study_duration: Administered at three different timepoints: before cocaine conditioning sessions, before extinction sessions, and before the reinstatement test

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) supplementation could improve inflammatory markers, oxidative stress, and antioxidant parameters in obese patients with non-alcoholic liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: OEA supplementation significantly improved oxidative stress and antioxidant biomarkers (increased TAC and SOD, decreased MDA and ox-LDL) but had no significant effect on inflammatory markers (hs-CRP, IL-1β, IL-6, IL-10, TNF-α).
population_specificity: 60 obese patients with NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) on PPARα-mediated microglia M2 polarization after cerebral ischemia.
results_summary: OEA promoted microglia switching from an inflammatory M1 to a protective M2 phenotype via PPARα activation, enhancing neuron survival after ischemic stroke. In vitro studies confirmed OEA's role in shifting microglia to an M2-like phenotype, improving neuronal survival under oxygen-glucose deprivation.
population_specificity: Wild-type and PPARα-knockout mice, mouse small glioma cells (BV2), and primary microglia cultures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) could mitigate stress-induced increased sensitivity to cocaine and its anti-inflammatory effects in the cerebellum.
results_summary: OEA pretreatment before social defeat or conditioning prevented cocaine-induced conditioned place preference (CPP) in stressed mice and reduced proinflammatory TLR4 upregulation in the cerebellum caused by social stress.
population_specificity: Adult OF1 mice subjected to social defeat stress.
effective_dosage: 10 mg/kg administered intraperitoneally (i.p.) 10 minutes before the corresponding event.
study_duration: Three weeks after the last social defeat encounter.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary oleic acid (OA) influences satiety and food intake through oleoylethanolamide (OEA) signaling.
results_summary: Mice fed a low-OA diet showed reduced jejunal OEA levels, increased food intake, and body weight gain, which were reversed by OA or OEA treatment, confirming OA's role in OEA-mediated satiety.
population_specificity: Mice
effective_dosage: OA diet (38.4 mg OA/g), low-OA diet (3.1 mg OA/g)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) could modulate lipid metabolism and microglia function to improve Alzheimer's disease (AD) pathology and cognitive impairments.
results_summary: The study found that OEA-PPARα signaling enhanced microglial Aβ uptake and clearance, suppressed lipid droplet accumulation and inflammasome activation, and improved cognitive function in 5xFAD mice. Chronic treatment with the OEA analog KDS-5104 reduced reactive gliosis and Aβ pathology.
population_specificity: 5xFAD mice (a model of Alzheimer's disease)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) supplementation on glycemic status, insulin resistance, and inflammatory factors in pre-diabetic individuals.
results_summary: OEA supplementation significantly reduced blood glucose, insulin, insulin resistance, HbA1c, and C-reactive protein levels in pre-diabetic individuals, with no significant changes observed in the placebo group.
population_specificity: Pre-diabetic individuals (n=46)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) could prevent vascular calcification and ferroptosis in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) under hyperlipidemia/palmitic acid exposure.
results_summary: OEA suppressed calcium deposition in hyperlipidemia-mediated rat aortas and PA-induced ferroptosis in VSMCs. It alleviated CGAS-STING1-induced ferritinophagy and mitochondrial DNA damage, with PPARα playing a key role in mediating OEA's anti-ferroptotic effects.
population_specificity: Rats with high-fat diet-induced vascular calcification and in vitro VSMCs exposed to palmitic acid.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) protects against doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity and to explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: OEA improved myocardial structure in mice by reducing oxidative stress and cell apoptosis caused by doxorubicin. These protective effects were mediated through TRPV1 activation and upregulation of the PI3K/Akt pathway.
population_specificity: Mice and HL-1 cardiomyocytes (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) as an add-on to standard stroke treatment improves inflammatory, oxidative stress, lipid, and biochemical parameters in acute ischemic stroke (AIS) patients.
results_summary: OEA at 300 mg/day significantly reduced multiple inflammatory, oxidative stress, and biochemical markers compared to baseline and placebo, while 600 mg/day only reduced malondialdehyde (MDA). The moderate dosage showed broader benefits, suggesting potential for improved long-term neurological outcomes.
population_specificity: 60 AIS patients (mean age 68.6, 48.33% female) admitted within 12 hours of symptom onset or last known well.
effective_dosage: 300 mg/day and 600 mg/day, administered for three days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the therapeutic potential of oleoylethanolamide (OEA) in restoring mitochondrial function and growth in lymphoblast cell lines derived from patients with Barth syndrome (BTHS).
results_summary: OEA treatment significantly restored mitochondrial membrane potential and colony growth in BTHS lymphoblasts, and improved mitochondrial size without affecting density or cristae lengths. However, it did not resolve cardiolipin deficits, suggesting its effects occur through alternative mechanisms.
population_specificity: Transformed lymphoblast cell lines derived from five patients with Barth syndrome (BTHS) and five healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) could protect against liver ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) injury by activating PPARα and reducing ER stress-associated apoptosis.
results_summary: OEA demonstrated a protective effect against liver I/R injury by reducing liver damage, lowering serum ALT and AST levels, and decreasing hepatocyte apoptosis. The mechanism involved PPARα activation, which regulated ER stress and reduced apoptosis.
population_specificity: Mouse model of partial warm ischemia-reperfusion and hypoxia-reoxygenation model of hepatocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) on oxidative stress and inflammatory factors in girls with primary dysmenorrhea.
results_summary: OEA supplementation significantly increased total antioxidant capacity (TAC) and reduced menstrual pain, malondialdehyde (MDA), C-reactive protein (CRP), and tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-α) compared to placebo. Intragroup changes in the intervention group were also statistically significant for these outcomes.
population_specificity: Female students with primary dysmenorrhea, as assessed by the visual analogue scale (VAS) questionnaire.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether loading Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) into lipid nanoparticles (OSDP LNPs) could improve its pharmaceutical properties and neuroprotective effects for stroke therapy.
results_summary: The study found that OSDP LNPs significantly improved OEA retention, neuroprotective effects, and therapeutic outcomes in MCAO rats, including survival rate, behavioral scores, cerebral infarct volume, edema reduction, and spatial learning/memory recovery.
population_specificity: Middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO) rats (animal model).
effective_dosage: Not specified (drug loading of 15.9 ± 1.2 wt% in LNPs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects and mechanisms of Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) on LPS/D-Gal-induced acute liver injury in mice.
results_summary: OEA treatment significantly reduced liver damage, oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis in mice with acute liver injury, likely through the Nrf-2/HO-1 and NLRP3 inflammasome pathways.
population_specificity: Mice with LPS/D-Gal-induced acute liver injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) supplementation combined with weight loss intervention on atherogenic indices and hematological parameters in obese patients with NAFLD.
results_summary: OEA supplementation significantly improved LDL-C/HDL-C, TG/HDL-C, and non-HDL-C/HDL-C ratios and reduced red blood cell distribution width (RDW) compared to placebo, with no significant effects on other hematological parameters.
population_specificity: Obese patients newly diagnosed with NAFLD confirmed by ultra-sonographic findings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the mechanism of Oleoylethanolamide's antiadipogenic effect in the liver, focusing on lipid composition and enzyme activity.
results_summary: OEA significantly reduced hepatic triacylglycerol content, altered sphingolipid composition, and decreased activity and expression of key enzymes involved in fatty acid and TAG synthesis. It also reduced SREBP-1 and PPARγ protein expression in the liver.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of oleoylethanolamide (OEA) in airway inflammation, specifically its effects on proinflammatory cytokines, eosinophilic inflammation, and activation of type 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2s) and eosinophils.
results_summary: OEA induced type 2 inflammatory responses in vitro and in vivo, increasing proinflammatory cytokines (IL-6, IL-8, IL-33) in airway epithelial cells and promoting eosinophilic inflammation, cytokine production (IL-4, IL-5, IL-13, IL-33), and airway hyperresponsiveness. OEA also activated ILC2s and increased CD69 expression on eosinophils from asthma patients.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice and human peripheral eosinophils from asthma patients and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) on preventing neuronal damage and neuroinflammation in Purkinje cell degeneration (PCD) mutant mice, assessing different doses and administration schedules.
results_summary: OEA treatment prevented morphological alterations in Purkinje neurons, reduced cell death, and improved motor, cognitive, and social functions in PCD mice, with acute administration (10 mg/kg) being most effective. The neuroprotective effects were mediated by PPARα receptors, and in vitro results suggested OEA normalized microtubule alterations.
population_specificity: Purkinje cell degeneration (PCD) mutant mice exhibiting cerebellar degeneration.
effective_dosage: 1, 5, and 10 mg/kg, intraperitoneal (i.p.), with acute administration on postnatal day 12 (10 mg/kg) being most effective.
study_duration: Chronic and acute administration schedules, with acute treatment on postnatal day 12.
interactions: PPARα antagonist GW6471 (2.5 mg/kg, i.p.) abolished OEA's effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oleoylethanolamide (OEA) could counteract thiamine deficiency-induced neuroinflammation and neurobehavioral alterations in murine models of Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome.
results_summary: Pretreatment with OEA prevented TLR4-induced neuroinflammation in the frontal cortex, incipient memory disability, and disinhibited-like behavior in thiamine-deficient mice. The study suggests OEA may serve as a co-adjuvant therapy to prevent neurobehavioral alterations in WKS.
population_specificity: Murine models of Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome (thiamine-deficient mice).
study_duration: Administered starting before any symptoms of pathology were manifested (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of oleoylethanolamide supplementation on the recovery trend in patients with COVID-19, focusing on clinical symptoms and preclinical features.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding oleoylethanolamide's effects, as the study appears to be ongoing or not yet concluded at the time of the abstract's publication.
population_specificity: Male and female patients ≥18 years with confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection, excluding severe/critical COVID-19 pneumonia, pregnancy, breastfeeding, and regular supplement users.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the therapeutic effects of oleoylethanolamide supplementation, alone or combined with boron citrate, in improving clinical and biochemical parameters in COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: Oleoylethanolamide in combination with boron citrate significantly reduced high-sensitivity C-reactive protein and interleukin-1β levels and improved common COVID-19 symptoms. No significant differences were found in hemoglobin, platelet count, or interleukin-6 levels compared to other groups.
population_specificity: Forty adult patients diagnosed with COVID-19.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) on inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), focusing on its anti-inflammatory properties and potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: OEA reduced inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-8, IL-1β) in vitro and improved colitis symptoms (body weight, disease activity index, colon length) in a rat model, likely via PPAR-α-mediated inhibition of NF-κB signaling.
population_specificity: Human embryonic kidney cells, human enterocytes (Caco-2), and rats with induced colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of OEA supplementation combined with calorie restriction on inflammation, body composition, and hepatic fibrosis in obese patients with NAFLD.
results_summary: OEA supplementation significantly reduced NF-κB and IL-6 expression, increased IL-10 expression, improved fat mass and fat-free mass, and elevated resting metabolic rate, but did not significantly affect NAFLD fibrosis scores.
population_specificity: Obese patients newly diagnosed with NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-binge effects of Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) in a rat model of binge-like eating and its potential as a treatment for binge eating disorder.
results_summary: OEA dose-dependently prevented binge-like eating in rats, reduced stress-related brain activation, modulated monoamine transmission, and restored normal oxytocin receptor density, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for binge eating behavior.
population_specificity: Female rats in a binge-like eating model induced by intermittent food restrictions/refeeding and palatable food exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) could serve as a potential pharmacological alternative for managing COVID-19 due to its anti-inflammatory, immune-modulating, and anti-oxidant properties.
results_summary: The study suggests that OEA may be effective in alleviating acute respiratory stress induced by COVID-19, based on its known health-promoting properties, but no specific clinical results are provided.
population_specificity: Not specified (general COVID-19 context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of OEA supplementation combined with weight loss intervention on gene expression, metabolic parameters, and anthropometric indices in obese patients with NAFLD.
results_summary: OEA supplementation significantly increased PPAR-α, UCP1, and UCP2 gene expression, improved metabolic parameters (e.g., reduced TG, ALT, AST, and increased HDL-C), and enhanced appetite sensations, though liver steatosis severity reduction was not statistically significant between groups.
population_specificity: Obese patients newly diagnosed with NAFLD (n=76).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic potential and mechanisms of Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) in hepatic glucose metabolism under type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), particularly its effects on glycogen synthesis and gluconeogenesis.
results_summary: OEA improved glucose homeostasis independently of PPARα, enhancing glycogen synthesis and suppressing gluconeogenesis via the LKB1/AMPK signaling pathways in mouse primary hepatocytes and liver tissue. The study suggests OEA's antidiabetic effects are mediated through these pathways, offering a potential therapeutic approach for T2DM.
population_specificity: Mouse primary hepatocytes and liver tissue (animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) could improve cognitive dysfunction in diabetic mice by activating PPARα signaling.
results_summary: OEA treatment significantly improved cognitive performance, reduced dementia markers, and protected against hippocampal neuron loss and neuroplasticity impairments in diabetic mice, but these effects were absent in PPARα knockout mice.
population_specificity: Diabetic C57BL/6J and PPARα--/- mice induced by high-fat diet and streptozotocin (HFD + STZ).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) supplementation on the abundance of Akkermansia muciniphila and dietary intakes in obese individuals.
results_summary: OEA supplementation significantly reduced energy and carbohydrate intakes and increased the abundance of A. muciniphila in obese individuals compared to placebo. The study suggests OEA as a safe and effective agent for modifying energy balance in obesity.
population_specificity: 60 obese individuals
effective_dosage: 125 mg of OEA twice daily (total 250 mg/day)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) on risk factors for non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: OEA was found to regulate biological processes linked to NAFLD, including lipid metabolism, inflammation, oxidative stress, and energy homeostasis, suggesting it may be an effective therapeutic strategy for NAFLD management. However, further clinical trials are needed to verify these outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) could regulate macrophage polarization and improve atherosclerotic plaque stability via the AMPK-PPARα pathway.
results_summary: OEA enhanced M2 macrophage markers (CD206, TGF-β) and reduced M1 markers (iNOS) in vitro, while in ApoE-/- mice, it promoted M2 polarization, increased collagen content, and reduced necrotic core size in plaques, mediated by PPARα.
population_specificity: THP-1-derived macrophages (in vitro) and ApoE-/- mice (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) modulates dendritic cell (DC) maturation and explore its underlying mechanism.
results_summary: OEA treatment decreased cell surface markers, reduced cell migration, diminished T cell proliferation, and regulated cytokine production in mature bone marrow-derived DCs. It suppressed DC maturation via TRPV1/AMPK activation, downregulating the TLR4/NF-κB pathway.
population_specificity: Bone marrow-derived dendritic cells (BMDCs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare plasma concentrations of Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) and related acylethanolamides in depressed patients versus healthy controls and assess the impact of SSRI therapy on these levels.
results_summary: Plasma OEA concentrations were elevated in depressed patients and correlated with somatic symptoms. Elevated levels of OEA and 2-AG were associated with SSRI antidepressant therapy, suggesting a potential role in SSRI response.
population_specificity: Primary care patients with depression (n=69) and healthy non-depressed controls (n=47).
interactions: SSRI antidepressant therapy was noted to elevate OEA and 2-AG levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of oleoylethanolamide (OEA) on monocyte migration and macrophage formation in the vascular wall, a key process in atherosclerosis.
results_summary: OEA showed dual-directional regulation of monocyte chemotaxis—stimulatory in a single-cell system and suppressive in a co-culture system—and reduced macrophage deposition in apoE-/- mice by inhibiting MCP-1 production via the AMPK/PPARα/STAT3 pathway.
population_specificity: In vitro monocyte-macrophage systems and apolipoprotein E (apoE)-/- mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the modulatory effects of Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) on intestinal microbiota and immune response in mice.
results_summary: Sub-chronic OEA administration altered the fecal microbiota profile, favoring Bacteroidetes over Firmicutes, and reduced intestinal cytokine expression, suggesting a shift toward a "lean-like phenotype" and mimicking the effects of a low-fat, high-polysaccharide diet.
population_specificity: Mice fed a normal chow pellet diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of oleoylethanolamide (OEA) supplementation on inflammatory biomarkers and oxidative stress in obese individuals.
results_summary: OEA supplementation significantly reduced IL-6 and TNF-α serum concentrations (p<0.001), indicating improved inflammation, but no significant changes were observed in other measured variables (MDA, TAS, hs-CRP).
population_specificity: 60 healthy obese individuals in Tabriz, Iran (56 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if targeting peroxisomal β-oxidation with Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) could restore lipid levels, reduce neuroinflammation, and improve neurobehavioral deficits in a mouse model of Gulf War Illness (GWI).
results_summary: OEA treatment in GWI mice resulted in cognitive benefits, reduced fatigue and disinhibition-like behavior, decreased neuroinflammation markers (e.g., reduced astroglia and microglia staining, lower chemokines/cytokines, and reduced NFκB phosphorylation), and normalized peroxisome-specific VLCFA levels in the brain.
population_specificity: Gulf War Illness (GWI) mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) supplementation on PPAR-α gene expression, appetite sensations, and anthropometric measurements in obese individuals.
results_summary: OEA supplementation significantly increased PPAR-α gene expression, reduced weight, BMI, waist circumference, and fat percentage, and improved appetite control by decreasing hunger, desire to eat, and cravings while increasing fullness.
population_specificity: 60 healthy obese individuals in Tabriz, Iran (56 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) could reduce neointima formation after vascular injury by suppressing vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) proliferation and migration, and to explore the underlying mechanisms involving AMPK and PPARα.
results_summary: OEA significantly reduced neointima formation in rats after balloon injury and inhibited PDGF-induced VSMC proliferation and migration in vitro. These effects were mediated through AMPK and PPARα activation, as pharmacological inhibition of these pathways reversed OEA's suppressive effects.
population_specificity: Rats (in vivo) and cultured vascular smooth muscle cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oleoylethanolamide (OEA) enhances the anorectic signaling and weight loss effects of GLP-1 receptor agonists (GLP-1RA) like exendin-4 (Ex4).
results_summary: OEA enhanced canonical GLP-1R signaling when combined with GLP-1 but not with Ex4. While OEA did not augment the hypophagic action of GLP-1 or Ex4, the combination of Ex4+OEA promoted greater weight loss in diet-induced obese (DIO) mice than either compound alone, due to transient hypophagia and increased energy expenditure.
population_specificity: Diet-induced obese (DIO) mice and lean mice.
interactions: Interaction with GLP-1 and Ex4 noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) in modulating lipid metabolism, energy intake, and its potential as a therapeutic agent for weight management and obesity treatment.
results_summary: The study found that OEA, derived from oleic acid, stimulates fatty acid uptake, lipolysis, and β-oxidation, and promotes food intake control, suggesting beneficial effects on body composition. Emerging evidence indicates OEA may mediate these responses through PPAR-α activation.
population_specificity: Humans (general, no specific subpopulation mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore Oleoylethanolamide's potential as a therapy for obesity by examining its effects on food intake and fat mass, focusing on its mechanisms in both homeostatic and hedonic brain centers.
results_summary: The study found that Oleoylethanolamide induces hypophagia and reduces fat mass in rodents, primarily mediated by PPAR-α signaling, with recent evidence suggesting additional effects via dopamine and endocannabinoid pathways. Limited human studies show encouraging but preliminary results, warranting further controlled investigations.
population_specificity: Rodents (primary focus), with limited human supplementation studies mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether encapsulating Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) in cubosomes could protect it from hydrolysis and enable therapeutic concentrations to reach the brain.
results_summary: The study found that OEA-loaded cubosomes maintained chemical stability, had a mean particle size under 200 nm, and could incorporate up to 30% w/w OEA without disrupting the cubosome nanostructure, suggesting potential for targeted brain delivery.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or preclinical study implied).
effective_dosage: Up to 30% w/w OEA relative to phytantriol.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) requires histamine signaling to exert its hypophagic effects and to compare OEA-induced neural activation in histamine-deficient (HDC-KO) and wild-type mice.
results_summary: OEA increased c-Fos expression in specific brain regions (SON, ARC, amygdala) of wild-type mice but not in HDC-KO mice, suggesting histamine-dependent mechanisms. OEA also increased oxytocin-immunostaining in the neurohypophysis of wild-type mice but not HDC-KO mice, while c-Fos expression in the nucleus of the solitary tract was elevated in both genotypes.
population_specificity: Histidine decarboxylase knockout (HDC-KO) mice and wild-type littermates.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective mechanisms of oleoylethanolamide (OEA) in acute cerebral ischemic injury, focusing on its antiapoptotic effects and signaling pathways.
results_summary: OEA treatment reduced cell apoptosis in ischemic stroke mice, suppressed Bax expression, and upregulated Bcl-2. It also inhibited TLR4/NF-κB and ERK1/2 signaling pathways, with effects dependent on PPARα activation.
population_specificity: Mouse model of transient focal cerebral ischemia induced by middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO).
effective_dosage: 40 mg/kg, intraperitoneal injection, single dose upon reperfusion.
study_duration: Single administration at reperfusion (90-minute occlusion followed by reperfusion).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize plasma acylethanolamides, including Oleoylethanolamide (OEA), in alcohol-dependent subjects and assess their potential as markers for alcohol abstinence.
results_summary: The study found that OEA and other acylethanolamides were significantly increased in alcohol-dependent patients compared to controls, with OEA, AEA, and DEA showing a negative correlation with the duration of alcohol abstinence, suggesting their potential as biomarkers for abstinence length.
population_specificity: 79 abstinent alcohol-dependent subjects (27 women) and age-/sex-/body mass-matched healthy volunteers (28 women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) could mitigate neuroinflammation, oxidative stress, and neuroprotective effects in rats exposed to binge ethanol administration.
results_summary: OEA pre-treatment blocked neuroinflammatory markers (HMGB1, TLR4, NF-kB), reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, MCP-1, TNF-α), prevented oxidative damage, and exhibited antidepressant-like effects during ethanol withdrawal.
population_specificity: Rats exposed to intragastric binge ethanol administration.
effective_dosage: 5 mg/kg, intraperitoneally, before each alcohol gavage (3 times/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) and NAPEs in regulating food intake and their potential as anti-obesity treatments.
results_summary: The study found that OEA acts as a satiety signal generated in the intestine upon fat ingestion, influencing central nervous system pathways to reduce food intake. NAPEs also demonstrated hypophagic effects, even in mice lacking the enzyme to convert them to NAEs, suggesting an independent role in feeding regulation.
population_specificity: Rats and mice (animal models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects and mechanisms of Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) in ameliorating hepatic fibrosis in mice models induced by a methionine choline-deficient diet or thioacetamide treatment.
results_summary: OEA significantly attenuated liver fibrosis progression by blocking hepatic stellate cell activation, reducing fibrosis markers, and inhibiting inflammation-related gene expression. These effects were mediated through PPAR-α activation, as they were absent in PPAR-α knockout mice.
population_specificity: Sv/129 mice with induced hepatic fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) is effective against depression and its role in regulating stress-related biomarkers.
results_summary: OEA normalized depression-like behaviors, reversed brain atrophy, and restored abnormal levels of stress and antioxidant markers, suggesting antidepressant effects linked to BDNF regulation, antioxidant defenses, and HPA axis normalization.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to chronic unpredictable mild stress (CUMS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) could regulate non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) caused by fat accumulation in high-fat diet-fed rats.
results_summary: OEA (5 mg/kg/day) improved NAFLD by regulating plasma lipid levels and liver inflammatory cytokines, promoting lipid β-oxidation via PPAR-α activation, and inhibiting lipogenesis independently of PPAR-α, showing higher efficacy and safety than fenofibrate.
population_specificity: Sprague Dawley (SD) rats fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antidepressant-like potential of Oleoylethanolamide (OEA) in mice and compare its effects to clomipramine (Cp).
results_summary: OEA treatment (2.5-10mg/kg) significantly reduced immobility in behavioral tests, increased 5-HTP-induced head twitch behavior, reversed reserpine-induced hypothermia, and elevated cerebral levels of noradrenaline (NE) and serotonin (5-HT), suggesting antidepressant effects via monoamine neurotransmitter regulation.
population_specificity: Mice (50 subjects, divided into 5 groups)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether phosphatidylcholine (PC) combined with ω-3 LCPUFA could be a potential treatment for anorexia nervosa (AN).
results_summary: The study suggests that choline and ω-3 LCPUFAs individually benefit mental health, and their combination may offer greater clinical effectiveness for AN, supported by literature on inflammation, gut-brain-axis, and nerve cell membrane function.
population_specificity: Patients with anorexia nervosa (AN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with DHA-PC and DHA-PS could alter lipid profiles in the brains of dementia-prone SAMP8 mice fed high-fat or low-fat diets.
results_summary: DHA-PC and DHA-PS restored lipid homeostasis in dementia mice, particularly recovering levels of DHA-containing PS and pPE, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for cognitive decline. High-fat diets reduced certain lipid biomarkers linked to Alzheimer’s prevention.
population_specificity: SAMP8 mice (a dementia-prone animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether phosphatidylcholine could improve the stability and efficacy of celecoxib-loaded casein nanoparticles for cancer treatment.
results_summary: Phosphatidylcholine significantly enhanced the stability of celecoxib-casein nanoparticles, improved intracellular uptake, and increased tumor inhibition rates in mice with A375 melanoma, comparable to paclitaxel. The modified nanoparticles also showed a 2.9-fold higher AUC in rats compared to unmodified nanoparticles.
population_specificity: Human malignant melanoma A375 cells, rats, and mice implanted with A375 tumors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate if polyenylphosphatidylcholine (PPC) as adjunctive therapy could improve liver function tests in Russian patients with NAFLD and associated metabolic comorbidities.
results_summary: The study found significant decreases in liver enzyme levels (ALT, AST, GGT) after 24 weeks of PPC treatment, with consistent improvements across all comorbidity subgroups. The results were statistically significant (p<0.001) and clinically relevant.
population_specificity: 2843 adult Russian patients with newly diagnosed NAFLD and at least one metabolic comorbidity (overweight/obesity, hypertension, type 2 diabetes, hypercholesterolaemia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate phosphatidylcholine PC ae C44:6 as a diagnostic biomarker for bacterial meningitis by comparing its concentrations in CSF across various neuroinflammatory and noninflammatory conditions.
results_summary: PC ae C44:6 concentrations were significantly higher in bacterial meningitis than in other conditions, showing strong diagnostic potential with high sensitivity and negative predictive value. It performed comparably to CSF cell count in distinguishing bacterial meningitis from viral or autoimmune causes and improved diagnostic accuracy when combined with cell count and lactate.
population_specificity: Patients with acute bacterial meningitis, neuroborreliosis, viral meningitis/encephalitis, autoimmune neuroinflammation, facial nerve and segmental herpes zoster, and noninflammatory CNS disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate if polyenylphosphatidylcholine (PPC) adjunctive therapy could improve ultrasonographic features of NAFLD in Russian patients with cardiometabolic comorbidities.
results_summary: The study found that PPC adjunctive therapy significantly improved liver echogenicity in 68.3% of patients and liver structure in 42.7% of patients after 24 weeks, with similar improvements observed across varying numbers of comorbidities.
population_specificity: 2843 adult Russian patients with newly diagnosed NAFLD and at least one cardiometabolic comorbidity (overweight/obesity, hypertension, type 2 diabetes, or hypercholesterolemia).
effective_dosage: 1.8 g of PPC administered three times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of phosphatidylcholine (PC) from milk fat globule membrane (MFGM) on inducing brown-like adipocytes in white adipose tissue (WAT) and its potential protective role against obesity and metabolic dysfunction.
results_summary: MFGM and PC improved glucose tolerance, insulin sensitivity, and induced browning of WAT by increasing thermogenic gene expression, mitochondrial function, and oxygen consumption. PC-mediated effects were partially dependent on PPARα activation.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6 J mice and in vitro models (C3H10T1/2 pluripotent stem cells, 3T3-L1 adipocytes, and stromal vascular cells from inguinal WAT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discover novel drug-like PC-PLC inhibitors as potential anticancer agents by identifying and testing structural analogues of benzenesulphonamides, pyrido[3,4-b]indoles, morpholinobenzoic acid, and benzamidobenzoic acid.
results_summary: The study identified promising PC-PLC inhibitors, with two pyrido[3,4-b]indoles (22_10 and 22_15) showing comparable or better potency than D609, and three morpholinobenzoic acids (84, 84_4, and 84_5) demonstrating superior potency. These findings support the potential development of drug-like PC-PLC inhibitors for anticancer treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or preclinical study implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of orally administered Phosphatidylcholine on intestinal barrier function and liver health in rats with drug-induced liver injury.
results_summary: PC therapy improved liver function, reduced portal pressure, decreased collagen fibers, repaired hepatocyte arrangement, lowered inflammatory cell infiltration, and reduced serum TNF-α and plasma endotoxin levels.
population_specificity: Rats with carbon tetrachloride-induced liver injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a highly sensitive method to detect and measure specific forms of phosphatidylcholine (PC) and phosphatidylethanolamine (PE) to study their substrate utilization by phospholipase A2 (PLA2) enzymes.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a UPLC ESI-MS/MS method capable of detecting PE and PC at levels as low as 50 femtomoles, validated its specificity through enzymatic assays and genetic downregulation, and demonstrated its application in monitoring PE and PC profiles in RAW 264.7 macrophages under treatment conditions.
population_specificity: RAW 264.7 macrophages (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess changes in phosphatidylcholine (PC. (18:3e/22:6)) levels as part of evaluating fecal microbiota transplantation's effects on intestinal metabolites in IgA nephropathy patients.
results_summary: The study found significant changes in phosphatidylcholine (PC. (18:3e/22:6)) levels post-FMT, correlating with alterations in intestinal microbiota and metabolites, suggesting a potential role in the therapeutic process.
population_specificity: Fifteen patients with IgA nephropathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of enzymes involved in phosphatidylcholine interconversion and their implications in various diseases, including oncological and metabolic disorders.
results_summary: The study discusses the biochemical properties of enzymes like PEMT, PTDSS1, PTDSS2, and PISD, their deregulation in diseases such as NAFLD, Alzheimer's, and diabetes, and reviews potential inhibitors as therapeutic agents.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on biochemical and disease mechanisms)
